title: Figma Launches Three AI-Powered Tools for Seamless In-App Image Editing

paragraphs.content: Figma announced three new AI-powered image editing tools—**Erase object**, **Isolate object**, and **Expand image**—on December 10, 2025, enabling precise edits directly within the platform without exporting to tools like Photoshop. These features consolidate with existing options like Remove background and Crop into a unified toolbar for faster access in Figma Design and Figma Draw. They target Professional, Organization, and Enterprise plan users with AI enabled, addressing common workflow gaps in refining visuals for UI mockups and marketing assets.

paragraphs.content: The tools emphasize granular control without text prompts, using an upgraded lasso for selections that preserve lighting, shadows, and backgrounds. A companion YouTube video demonstrates their efficiency, showing how designers can isolate, erase, or extend images seamlessly on the canvas. This launch positions Figma as a more complete creative hub, reducing reliance on multiple apps for everyday edits.

sections.title: Breakdown of Erase, Isolate, and Expand Capabilities

paragraphs.content: **Erase object** lets users select and remove unwanted elements via the lasso tool, intelligently filling in backgrounds while maintaining color, focus, and details—no prompts needed. **Isolate object** separates subjects for repositioning or effects like blur, desaturation, lighting tweaks, or color adjustments, retaining image integrity. These join a toolbar prioritizing background removal, Figma's most common image task, for streamlined UI and brand work.

paragraphs.content: **Expand image** extends backgrounds to new aspect ratios, such as turning square product shots into landscape banners without distortion, ideal for web or mobile adaptations. Figma's blog describes this as closing "the loop on these workflows," enabling precise manipulation all in one file. The unified toolbar consolidates editing for quicker access during design iterations.

paragraphs.content: The new toolbar groups all image tools, including annotations and background changes, cutting time on frequent actions like asset optimization for campaigns. ContentGrip highlights benefits for marketers, such as in-house edits reducing design team handoffs and faster test variations. This setup supports cross-functional reviews with on-the-fly tweaks, minimizing platform switches.

Broader rollout across Figma products is planned for 2026, building on 2025's AI enhancements like credit tracking. YouTube demos reinforce the anti-juggling message, showing edits without leaving files for cleaner processes. Industry views frame this as workflow optimization, empowering non-experts in visual refinement.
